messages: abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (18:11): Quick question: how would you define the difference between HTML5 and HTML 5? (i.e. no space vs. with space)

002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:13): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: Some people use HTML5 to refer to the text/html serialization and HTML 5 to refer to the spec. Other people make no distinction. The spec only defines "HTML 5".

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:13): In most usages, it doesn't matter.  At times it is helpful to contrast HTML 5 (with a space, referring to the vocabulary) from the two concrete serializations HTML5 (quotes not required on attributes) and XHTML5 (draconian).
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:14): 002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570: section 1.7 defines "HTML5"
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:14): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: Stop assuming I know what the spec says! :P
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (18:16): and what methodology led to distinguishing semantics (the spec/vocabulary vs. a serialization) based on a single space character?
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:16): guesses it was the fact the spec wasn't called HTML 5 until the W3C got involved
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:17): like all decisions at the WHATWG, I presume that it was based on data  and reasoning (the way the WHATWG operates)[TM]

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (18:17): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d - you're better than that - no need for snark

002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:20): (As it was Web Applications 1.0  before)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:43): anyone who makes a distinction between HTML5 and HTML 5 (with/without space) as referring to the serialisation and vocabularly, respectively, is wrong.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:43): The distiction can only be made based on context
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:44): or, where it's not entirely clear, by explicitly qualifying it as, e.g., "HTML5 syntax" or "HTML5 vocabularly"
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (18:45): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 - the spec itself tries to make such a distinction, and as such is quite confusing.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:46): the spec is wrong
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:46): While it might be nice in theory to have such a distinction, in reality, we don't because we can't make people use them consistently

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:47): there was a big discussion about this a year or two ago, with many people wanting to find an alternative name for it. We had all sorts of weird and wonderful suggestions
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:47): like calling the serialisation "tHTML", which was short for text/html or something

Since that point, the spec (as you note) makes that distinction.  I share f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220's opinion that the spec is wrong on this totally minor and nearly irrelevant point.
